title: Wawrinka Announces Retirement Plans for 2026
summary: Stan Wawrinka, a three-time Grand Slam champion from Switzerland, has declared that 2026 will mark the end of his professional tennis career. At 40 years old, Wawrinka reflected on his achievements, including victories over tennis legends Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal in major finals, such as the 2015 French Open and 2016 US Open. He described this decision as writing the 'final chapter' of his career, emphasizing his desire to push his limits and finish on a positive note. Wawrinka turned professional in 2002 and has accumulated 16 tour-level titles, along with an Olympic gold medal in doubles from the 2008 Beijing Games with Roger Federer. Despite recent injuries and a ranking outside the top 150, he remains motivated by dreams and the emotional connection with fans. His final season will commence at the United Cup in Perth in January 2026, as he looks forward to global farewell appearances. This announcement highlights the challenges and triumphs of a player who succeeded during the dominant 'Big Three' era in tennis.

background_read: Stan Wawrinka is a Swiss professional tennis player known for his powerful one-handed backhand and success during the 'Big Three' era dominated by Novak Djokovic, Rafael Nadal, and Roger Federer. He turned pro in 2002 and rose to a career-high ranking of world number three. Wawrinka's major achievements include winning three Grand Slam titles: the 2014 Australian Open (defeating Nadal), the 2015 French Open (defeating Djokovic), and the 2016 US Open (defeating Djokovic). He also won 16 ATP tour titles and an Olympic gold medal in doubles at the 2008 Beijing Games with Federer. In recent years, injuries have affected his performance, dropping his ranking outside the top 150. His retirement announcement for 2026 reflects a common trend in sports where athletes plan their exits to maximize legacy and fan engagement, as seen in other tennis stars like Serena Williams.
